summary.seg: This medical handbook was written in the late 14th- to early 15th-century, possibly somewhere in East Anglia, and contains texts mostly in Middle English, with some in Latin and French. It consists of four distinct codicologial units, written roughly at the same time by different scribes in slightly different scripts. Each unit is set apart from the others by some originally blank spaces or leaves, pointing to their separate production as booklets (f. 14v at the end of Unit 1; 33r-33v at the end of Unit 2; 106v-109v at the end of Unit 3). These blank spaces were soon filled by other hands writing various recipes, charms or other medical notes. This, and the coherence of the manuscript's textual contents, suggests that the four parts were intended to be bound as one, or were brought together at an early stage. The manuscript shows further signs of sustained use: many of the pages are discoloured or stained, an added recipe has been cancelled (f. 33v), the margins include various 'nota bene' and pointing hands (known as maniculae) highlighting interesting points in the texts, and the calendar at the beginning (ff. 2v-12v, now incomplete) has received various additions and annotations.

The main part of the manuscript comprises various medical recipes ranging from cures for toothaches, nosebleeds and stomach aches to a recipe for surgical anaesthetic known as 'dwale' (f. 79r-79v). A significant portion is also dedicated to various treatises on urine and its uses for diagnostics, including a translation into Middle English of Walter of Agilon's Commentary on Urine (ff. 119r-125v). The medical content is framed by single leaves at the end and at the beginning whose contents illustrate the connection in the late medieval period between medical practice and astrology (f. 1r-1v) and lunar cycles (f. 126r-126v). The Calendar furthermore contains not only lists of saints' days, as is typical, but also related tables of astrological calculations. This particular combination of astrological and diagnostic material is frequently found in the folding almanacs that were being produced around the same time. Their presentation here illustrates the different formats in which this information could be presented in the medieval period, and illustrates the integration of recipes and cures into broader astrological-medical practice.

Tuija Ainonen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Zodiac figure
msItem.incipit: 1r Aries Caue ab incisione in capite uel in facie et ne insindes venam capitalem
msItem.explicit: 1r Pisces Caue ne insindaris in pedibus dum ibi manet luna scilicet februario et martio et sol

msItem.title: Table of zodiac signs and months
Calendar with tables
msItem.note: Lacking February and June, ff. 2r and 14v blank except for added medical recipes, the last headed "Dominus William Howheton". Thomas of Canterbury and his translation not erased.

msItem.title: Recipes for gilding and colouring
msItem.rubric: 17r How þou schalt temper þi colourus to lymninge and how þou schal make a syse to kowche golt on bokus

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: For treatment of lice, plague, migrane etc. Latin text on bathing. Added in multiple different 15th-century hands. Fol. 19v blank except for Ave Maria prayer.

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.note: List of 231 entries for the collection of recipes on ff. 34r-106v. Page numbers in red ink on the top margins of these folios are used in the table of contents to indicate where particular recipes can be found.

msItem.title: Treatise on urines
msItem.incipit: 26r Her begynns þat is borston taak reed banworth
msItem.explicit: 30r and red it signifiez þe flux of blod etcetera.
msItem.note: Treatise on the 20 colours of urine, the significance of the colours and division into four parts.

msItem.title: Medical treatise 'Tokens of Ipocras'
msItem.incipit: 30r Her begyns þe takyns þat ypocras þe leche wrot
msItem.explicit: 32v þat he schal dye þe same day.

msItem.title: Treatise on urine (extract from 'Letter of Ipocras')
msItem.incipit: 32v þe urine þat is drowvy and whith sinifiez
msItem.explicit: 33r he haue þe feuer agu be hit man or woman signifiez deeþ

msItem.title: Treatise on urines (incomplete)
msItem.incipit: 33r Fatnes on þe watur wastinge of flesch

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: Added by another 15th-century hand. Another medical recipe crossed out and barely visible on the lower part of the folio.

msItem.title: Medical recipes and charms
msItem.incipit: 34r For þe heued ake take and sethe uerueyne
msItem.explicit: 106r and drinke wiþ ale first and last.
msItem.note: The recipes and charms correspond closely to the table of contents on ff. 20r-25r.
Some losses due to missing ff. 51, 53, 59, 61, 102. Additions by other 15th-16th century hands on ff. 106r-v, and on the margins of ff. 34r, 61v, 79v, 85r.
Charm on fol. 62r, not in IMEV/S 624 (Ihesu þat was in bethleem born / and baptised was in flum iordan...).

msItem.title: Glossary of herbs
msItem.incipit: Deisi habet nome peti consond brese wort mene consonde bursa pastor
msItem.note: Macaronic list added with the same 15th-century hand as the text above.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 106v For þe colic take anys iij partyes
msItem.explicit: 109v and þen caste þe foom awey.
msItem.note: 31 recipes mostly for the stomach and digestion, written by several hands, some added in the margins.

msItem.title: Treatise on urines
msItem.rubric: 110r De regionibus urine of regions of þe uryne
msItem.incipit: 110r Ureyne is a watur or a watury substance
msItem.note: Unidentified treatise on urine, the following treatise might be part of the same composition.
Dialect supposedly Herefordshire (LALME) (Binski and Zutshi, no. 221).

msItem.title: Commentarium urinarum
msItem.author: Walter Agilon
msItem.rubric: 119r Iudicium vrinarium secundum magistrum Galterium agilon
msItem.incipit: 119r Condiciouns þt we ow to kepe
msItem.explicit: 125v and þerfor hit is ful perelus.
msItem.note: By the same hand as the previous item. The Middle English translation generally matches the other forms of the long catalogue of uroscopic signs in other Middle English translation of Walter Agilon's treatise, though with differences to suggests that it might be a third and incomplete version fot he same Latin original. (see IMEP 19, p. 37 M. Connolly's personal commuinication with T. Tavormina).
Dialect supposedly Herefordshire (LALME) (Binski and Zutshi, no. 221).

msItem.title: Table of eclipses
msItem.note: The table contains figures, times and durations of 30 eclipses. The first is June 1406, the last in 1443.

foliation.note: Folio numbers 6, 15, 16, 51, 53, 59, 61 and 102 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). Unnumbered leaf missing immediately preceding 17.

collation.formula: Single leaf, 18 (2nd and 6th leaf missing) 28 (7th and 8th leaves cancelled); 310 (unnumbered 1st leaf not present) 4-68; 78 (2nd and 4th leaves not present) 88 (2nd and 4th leaves not present) 9-108 11-126 138 148 (1st leaf missing); 15-168, single leaf

signatures.p: Leaf signatures written in black ink: e, f and h plus Roman numerals for Quires 9, 10 and 12. Mostly cropped.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the lower margins of last versos of quires 6-13 and 15 (ff. 49v, 57v, 65v, 73v, 81v, 87v, 93v, 102v, 117v), unframed (except framed in red at the end of quire 5, and framed in red and in brown at the end of quire 15). One catchword written in red ink (f. 41v), where the opening text on the following leaf is a rubric.

p.seg: Folios 2r-14r: Frame- and line ruled in red ink. Calendar has 13 and tables 22 columns. 36 lines to the page, with first and last double horizontal bounding lines extending to the margins, and first, fourth, seventh, tenth and thirteenth and last double vertical bounding lines with first and last extending to the margins. Written below top line. Folio 14v unruled.

Folios 17r-19v: Unruled, written ad hoc. Folios 20r-25v: Ruled in brown ink, frame only. Fols. 26r-33r: Ruled first in red ink, from f. 27v onward in brown ink, frame only. Mainly in single columns (except ff. 27r-30r which has narrow left columns for illustrations). 24-27 lines per page, written below top line.

Folios 34r-109v: Frame- and line ruled in brown ink. Single columns. 22 lines to page, written below top line. The vertical bounding lines, and the first two and last two horizontal bounding lines extending to the margins. Pricking visible on the top and bottom margin, and occasionally on outer margins. Added material on ff. 106r-109v written on ruled pages, but not always following the lines.

Folios 110r-125v: Frame- and line ruled in brown ink. Single column, 22 lines to page, written below top line. The vertical bounding lines, and the first two and the last horizontal bounding lines occasionally extending to the margins. Pricking visible on the top margin, and outer margins.

handDesc.summary: Multiple scribal hands, main hands for each codicological unit as follows:

handNote.p: Various Gothic bookhands (cursiva, textualis and hybrida).

decoNote.p: 1r: Zodiac Man: a male figure with animals representing the twelve zodiac signs, distributed across his body; with captions.
27r-30r: Thirty-four coloured jordans (urinary flasks); ff. 32v-33r three additional jordans without colour.

2v-14r Each calendar month on the verso is followed by an astronomical table on the facing recto, with additional astronomical tables on ff. 13v-14r. Numbers and writing in red ink in calendars and the diagrams.
126r-v Diagrams of eclipses coloured in red and oxidized silver(?).

decoDesc.decoNote: Raised burnished gold initials, filled and surrounded by purple penwork flourishes (ff. 2v, 3v, 4v, 5v, 7v, 8v, 9v, 10v, 11v, 34r, 110r).
Pen-work initials in blue with red florishes (ff. 20r, 111r-119v).
Alternating gold and blue one-line initials with purple or red flourishes (ff. 2v, 3v, 4v, 5v, 7v, 8v, 9v, 10v, 11v).

decoNote.p: Blue or red penwork initials throughout.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials in the margin occasionally filled with yellow ink (ff. 120r-124r).

note.p: Collation formula by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L., c. 1958 (inside right cover).

binding.p: Binding by GrayGray of Cambridge, dated 1958 by a note on the front pastedown. Millboard quarter binding with marbled paper covering and brown leather spine. The title and classmark are tooled in gold on the spine.

origin.origDate: Late 14th century and the first half of the 15th century
origin.p: Calendar principally Sarum with variations pointing to East Anglia: Winwaloe, Withburga (3, 16 March), translation of Edmund, in red (28 April), Radegund (13 Aug.); also Dominic (5 Aug.). (Binski and Zutshi, no. 221).

provenance.p: 'Hedyngton mouls/monk(?)': inscription by a 15th-century hand, above an erased recipe (f. 2r).

Perhaps John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : attributed to Moore by Binski and Zutshi, but not recorded or identified in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697), or Thomas Tanner's supplementary handlist (MS Oo.7.50(2)).

history.acquisition: Perhaps presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on inside left cover (but in some instances these bookplates were mistakenly added to books at the University Library that had not been part of Moore's library: see David McKitterick, 'Cambridge University Library: A History').

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press); and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. JamesJames, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
